element.name: TfpgWidget.SetPosition
element.short: Sets the position and size of the component
element.descr: . It also fires the Resize message. If you are setting up a component like a button on a form, you don't really want the resize event to fire for the button, before the form is displayed (visible). In that case, rather use the components Top, Left, Width and Height properties.

element.name: TfpgWidget.FormDesigner
element.short: If assigned, then this widget is being editing in the Form Designer

element.name: TfpgWidget.Parent
element.descr: Unlike Delphi or Lazarus, fpGUI treats Owner and Parent as the same thing. Owner or Parent manages the life of children, and the parent/child hierarchy defines the visual aspect as well.

element.name: TfpgWidget.IsContainer
element.short: Can this component managed child components
element.descr: This is mainly used in fpGUI UI Designer, to know if you can drop on widget inside another widget.

element.name: TfpgWidget.Focusable
element.short: This determines if the widget is allowed to received keyboard focus
element.descr: . No focus rectangle will be drawn, even if the user clicks this component.

element.name: TfpgWidget.Anchors
element.short: Allows the component to resize or reposition based on its Parent.

descr.p: By default Anchors are set to Top Left.
descr.remark: Anchoring only takes affect after the component is visible on the screen (when the component has a window handle assigned). So if you create a Button in the constructor and set its Anchor property to Bottom/Right, and then set the size of the Form, the Button will not be repositioned.
descr.p: This is by design. fpGUI allows you to setup a window layout without triggering unnecesary events as you set property values for each widget. Only when csLoading is not in ComponentState, then anchoring events will be triggered. This allows the developer or the fpGUI UI Designer to setup a window layout undisturbed.

element.name: TfpgWidget.HandleLMouseUp
element.short: Occurs after the component processed the mouse button press event
element.descr: . By default this method also triggers the OnClick event, but this behaviour can be overridden by descendant components.
